Documentation for the Code¶

A N-Body Simulation Code.

initialConditions¶

nbody.initialConditions.PlummerDist(N, dim, a, rand=<module 'numpy.random' from '/Users/lxy/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/random/__init__.py'>)[source]¶

Initializes particles with Plummer density profile.

Parameters

  • N (int) – number of particles

  • dim (int) – dimension

  • a (int) – Plummer radius

  • rand (func, optional) – random generate function. Defaults to np.random.

Returns

(N x dim) array of positions

Return type

[np.array]

nbody.initialConditions.escapeV_Plummer(r, M, a, G)[source]¶
Compute the escape velocity at a radius r from the center of the

Plummer sphere

Parameters

  • r (float) – radius away from the center of the Plummer sphere

  • M (float) – total mass of the Plummer sphere

  • a (float) – plummer radius

  • G (float) – gravitational constant

Returns

escape velocity of a particle at radius r inside a Plummer sphere

Return type

[float]

nbody.initialConditions.plummer(N, dim: int, a, m=1.0, G=0.004483, seed=None)[source]¶

Compute the positions and velocities of particles in the Plummer sphere

Parameters

  • N (int) – number of particles

  • dim (int) – dimension

  • a (int) – Plummer radius

  • m ([int], optional) – mass of particles can be a single value or an array of values. Defaults to 1..

  • G (int, optional) – Gravitational constant. Defaults to 4.483e-3.

  • seed (int, optional) – random generator seed.

Returns

[(N x dim), (N x dim)] positions and velocities of particles in the Plummer sphere

Return type

[pos, vel]

nbody.initialConditions.rejV_Plummer(r, dim, M, a, G, rand=<module 'numpy.random' from '/Users/lxy/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/random/__init__.py'>)[source]¶

Uses the rejection technique to find the velocity drawn randomly from the velocity distribution

Parameters

  • r (float) – radius from the center of the Plummer sphere

  • dim (int) – dimension

  • M (float) – total mass of the Plummer sphere

  • a (float) – Plummer radius

  • G (float) – gravitational constant

  • rand (func, optional) – RandomState generator. Defaults to np.random.

Returns

velocity of a particle

Return type

[float]

nbody.initialConditions.velDist_Plummer(N, dim, r, M, a, G, rand=<module 'numpy.random' from '/Users/lxy/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/random/__init__.py'>)[source]¶

Compute velocities from the velocity distribution of particles of the Plummer model.

Parameters

  • N (int) – total number of particles to be initialized

  • dim (int) – dimension

  • r (float) – radius from the center of the Plummer sphere

  • M (float) – total mass of the Plummer sphere

  • a (float) – Plummer radius

  • G (float) – gravitational constant

  • rand (func, optional) – RandomState generator. Defaults to np.random.

Returns

(N, dim) array of velocities of particles

Return type

[np.array]

class nbody.tree.tree(particles, masses, cell)[source]¶
accel(theta, particle_id, G, eps=0.1)[source]¶

Calculate acceleration for a given particle with some tolerance theta

Parameters

  • theta (float) – the scale that define how far the particles we should treat as a single mass

  • particle_id (int) – the id of the particle, used to fetch particle’s cell instance

  • G (float) – gravitational constant

  • eps (float, optional) – the force softening factor. Defaults to 0.1.

Returns

(dim, ) the force felt by the particle (id)

Return type

[np.array]

the root cell object

Return type

[node]

get_all_leaves(n)[source]¶

Get all the leaves of this node

Parameters

n (node) – a node object whoes leaves are to be added

traverse(n0, n1, theta, idx, G, eps=0.01)[source]¶

Recursively compute the force of exterted by n0 on n1. It will traverse the tree far enough so that we can treat the particles as a single mass

Parameters

  • n0 (cell) – the object exerting the force

  • n1 (cell) – the obhject feel the force

  • theta (float) – the scale that define how far the particles we should treat as a single mass

  • idx (int) – id of n1

  • G (float) – gravitational constant

  • eps (float, optional) – the force softening factor. Defaults to 0.01.

Returns

(dim, 1) the force felt by the particle (id)

Return type

[np.array]

integrator¶

nbody.integrator.serial_timestep(x, v, a, dt)[source]¶

Returns the updated positions (p) and velocities (v) given accelerations (a) and a timestep dt, using the leap-frog algorithm.

Parameters

  • x (np.array) – positions (N x d)

  • v (np.array)) – velocities (N x d)

  • a (np.array) – accelerations (N x d)

  • dt (float) – time step

Returns

new positions (N x d), new velocites (N x d)

Return type

[np.array, np.array]

utils¶

class nbody.utils.RunResults(run_name)[source]¶

Class for loading and analyzing results from behalf runs

nbody.utils.compute_energy(pos, vel, mass=None, G=0.004483)[source]¶

Returns the total energy of the system defined by input positions (pos), velocities (vel), and masses (defaults to 1.0 for all particles), using units defined by choice of G.

Total energy is the sum of potential and kinetic energy (see: compute_potential_energy and compute_kinetic_energy)

Input:

pos - positions (N x d) vel - velocities (N x d) mass - masses (optonal. Default: np.ones(N)) G - Newton’s Constant (optional. Default=1.)

Output:

E - total energy (float)

nbody.utils.compute_kinetic_energy(vel, mass=None)[source]¶

Returns the kinetic of the system defined by input velocities and mass (defaults to 1.0 for all particles).

Kinetic energy is defined as: K = 1/2 sum_i (mass[i] * ||vel[i]||**2)

Input:

vel - velocities (N x 3) mass - masses (optonal. Default: np.ones(N))

Output:

K - kinetic energy (float)

nbody.utils.compute_potential_energy(pos, mass=None, G=0.004483)[source]¶

Returns the gravitational potential energy of the system defined by input positions (pos) and masses (defaults to 1.0 for all particles), using units defined by choice of G.

Potential energy is defined as: U = - sum_i ( sum_[j > i] ( G * mass[i] * mass[j] / r_ij)) r_ij = || pos[i] - pos[j] ||

Input:

pos - positions (N x d) mass - masses (optonal. Default: np.ones(N)) G - Newton’s Constant (optional. Default=1.)

Output:

U - Gravitational potential energy (float)

nbody.utils.parse_name(run_name)[source]¶

Parses the run name into number of cores, nodes, gpus, particles, steps, and dt

Format:

AAA_B-C_D_E_F

AAA - Run Type (gpu, mpi, etc) B - Number of cores C - Number of nodes D - Number of particles E - Number of time steps F - Time Precision (1 / dt_Myr)

nbody.utils.save_results(out_file, pos, vel, mass, t_start, iter_num, iter_total, num_cores, G=0.004483, timers=None)[source]¶

Saves the current state of the simulation to “out_file”.

Input:

out_file - filename to save results to pos - array of particle positions (N x d) vel - array of particle velocities (N x d) mass - array of particle masses (N) t_start - start time (in seconds) of the simulation iter_num - current time step of the simulation iter_total - total number of iterations the simulation will run for num_cores - number of cores used for computation timers - TimerCollection of custom timers to save

nbody.utils.split_size(N_parts, N_chunks, i)[source]¶

Returns number of particles (out of N_parts) distributed to chunk i of N_chunks

Input:

N_parts - number of particles (int) N_chunks - number of chunks to distribute to (int) i - which chunk to compute number of particles (int, 0-indexed)

Example: splitting 1000 particles across 10 chunks >>> split_size(1000, 11, 0) 91 >>> split_size(1000, 11, 10) 90
